text:
They were quiet for a bit. 

“Hmm... that’s interesting,” Raskolnikov muttered. “I thought maybe I imagined it.” 

“What do you mean?” Razumihin asked, confused. 

“Well, you all keep saying I’m losing it,” Raskolnikov said, forcing a smile. “I wondered if I really am crazy and just saw a ghost.” 

“What do you mean?” 

“Who knows? Maybe I’m really losing it, and everything that’s happened lately is just in my head.” 

“Come on, Rodya, you’re stressed again! But what did he say? Why was he here?” 

Raskolnikov didn’t respond. Razumihin thought for a moment. 

“Let me tell you what happened to me,” he started. “I came to see you, and you were out cold. We had dinner, then I went to Porfiry’s. Zametov was still there. I tried to talk, but it just wasn’t happening. They don’t get it and aren’t even embarrassed. I pulled Porfiry to the window to chat, but it didn’t help. We both just stared off into space. Finally, I lost it and told him I’d knock him out. He just looked at me, so I cursed and left. That was it. Super awkward. Didn’t say a word to Zametov. Thought I messed it all up, but then I had a great idea as I was heading downstairs: why...

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov questions his sanity and the reality of his experiences, contemplating the possibility that everything may be mere imagination.
